questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of chronic kidney diseases (CKD) and diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years presents for routine kidney function evaluation. To assess renal function accurately, which of the following is considered the best method to measure her GFR in a clinical setting?
questions.explanation:
GFR = 141 × min(Scr/κ, 1)α × max(Scr/κ, 1)-1.209 × 0.993Age
  • SCr is serum creatinine in mg/dL,
  • κ is 0.7 for females and 0.9 for males,
  • α is –0.329 for females and –0.411 for males,
  • min indicates the minimum of SCr/κ or 1,
  • and max indicates the maximum of SCr/κ or 1.
  • Multiply by 1.018 if the patient is a woman
  • Multiply by 1.159 for people with African ancestry

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient weighs 80 kg, is 175 cm tall, and has a serum creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. Using the Cockcroft-Gault equation, what is this patient's estimated Glomerular filtration rate?
questions.explanation: CrCl = (140 - age in years) × weight in kg / (72 × serum creatinine in mg/dL) × 0.85 (if female, as they have less muscle mass)

questions.text: A 66-year-old male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the ICU following major cardiac surgery. Post-operatively, his urine output has decreased significantly, raising concerns about acute kidney injury (AKI). Which of the following investigations would be most useful for early detection of AKI in this patient?
questions.explanation:
BIOMARKERS for early detection of AKI

NGAL

Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin

  • Useful for early detection of acute kidney injury (AKI), particularly following cardiopulmonary bypass surgery.
  • It can be measured in both urine and plasma, providing a rapid and sensitive indication of kidney damage before significant changes in traditional markers like serum creatinine are observed.

KIM-1

Kidney injury molecule - 1

  • Type 1 transmembrane protein in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the kidney, upregulated in response to injury.
  • Tested in urine and plasma

suPAR

Soluble urokinase plasminogen-activating receptor

  • Signalling glycoprotein.
  • Tested in only plasma.

IGFBP7

Insulin-like growth factor binding protein 7 and tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase-2 are being used as predictive biomarkers for the high risk of development of moderate to severe AKI in critically ill patients.

TIMP-2

Biomarkers for early detection of AKI
  • NGAL (Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin)
  • KIM-1 (Kidney injury molecule - 1)
  • suPAR (Soluble urokinase plasminogen-activating receptor)
  • IGFBP7 (Insulin-like growth factor binding protein 7)
  • TIMP-2 (Tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase-2)

questions.text: A 78-year-old female patient with a history of diabetes mellitus presents to the outpatient department for her annual checkup. She reports no new complaints and appears to be in good health. Routine investigations reveal the following results: Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR): 50 mL/min Urine Albumin Levels: 12 mg/g Based on the kidney disease improving global outcome classification of CKD, what is the risk of kidney failure in this patient?
questions.explanation:
G

F

R

 

Prognosis of CKD, according to

KDIGO 2012 classification

Persistent albuminuria

A1

A2

A3

Moderate increase

Severe increase

<30mg/g

30-300 mg/g

>300mg/g

Normal or high

Low risk

Moderate risk

60-89

45-59

30-44

G4

Very high risk

<15

Very high risk

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with worsening fatigue, leg swelling, and occasional shortness of breath. He has a 15-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Laboratory tests show elevated serum creatinine and a reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Which of the following diseases is least likely to have caused his condition?
questions.explanation:
CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE

Risk factors

  • Chronic systemic diseases
    • Diabetes and metabolic syndromes
    • Autoinflammatory disorders: SLE, Vasculitis
    • Infections: HIV, HBV, HCV
    • Toxic exposure: Antineoplastic agents
    • Hypertension
  • Lifestyle
    • Smoking
    • Diet
    • Physical activity

Leading causes

  • Diabetic nephropathy (Most common)
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Hypertension
  • Ischemic heart disease (Cardiorenal syndrome)
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
  • Tubulointerstitial kidney disease

Manifestation

  • Weight loss
  • Nausea
  • Hiccups (urea irritates gastric mucosa)
  • Pedal oedema
  • Muscle cramping and twitching
  • Pruritus and skin pigmentation
  • Uremic fetor
  • Restless leg syndrome
  • Uremic pericarditis
  • Hypertension

questions.text: A 74-year-old male with stage 3 chronic kidney disease presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, and palpitations. His current medications include losartan and spironolactone for hypertension. ECG findings are normal. Serum electrolyte levels are given below. Sodium - 129 mEq/L Potassium - 5.6 mEq/L Bicarbonate - 20 mEq/L Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management of this patient’s electrolyte abnormalities?

options.label: C
options.text: Stop spironolactone and start on patiromer

questions.correct_answer: C. Stop spironolactone and start on patiromer
questions.explanation:
Fluid and serum electrolytes in CKD

Electrolyte Imbalances

Management

Hypervolemic hyponatremia:

  • High circulating aldosterone levels.
  • Increase in water > sodium retention.
  • Water restriction

Hyperkalemia
  • Patiromer (Option C)
  • Calcium resonium
  • Sodium polystyrene

Hypokalemia (rare): Usually due to overuse of diuretics
  • Increase dietary intake and reduce the dose of diuretics

Hyperphosphatemia

  • Sevelamer
  • Calcium acetate or carbonate

Hypocalcemia
  • Paricalcitol

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease presents for routine follow-up. Her HbA1c is 5.6%, blood pressure is 152/88 mmHg, serum creatinine is 1.8 mg/dL, and urinalysis shows microalbuminuria. She is currently taking Canagliflozin and hydrochlorothiazide. Which medication should be added to her treatment?
questions.explanation:
Management of Chronic kidney disease

Blood glucose control

HbA1c < 7%

  • Metformin may be given if eGFR>30ml/min, or else lactic acidosis may occur
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors (Canagliflozin, Dapagliflozin) can prevent diabetic nephropathy.
  • Insulin should be given to achieve the HbA1c target.

Blood pressure control

Target BP <130/80 mm hg

  • ACEi: Lisinopril, Captopril (Option B)
  • ARB’s: Losartan, Telmisartan
    • ACEi and ARB have nephroprotective activity and thus should be used as the preferred drug of choice to control BP (Option B).
  • Calcium channel blockers can be used if ACEi are contraindicated.

Cholesterol

Target LDL<70 mg%

  • Statins: Atorvastatin 40 to 80 mg

Anemia
  • IV iron
  • Erythropoietin stimulating agents: Darbepoetin and epoetin

Coagulopathies

  • Desmopressin
  • Cryoprecipitate
  • Conjugated estrogen
  • Blood transfusion

Vitamin D deficiency

  • Vitamin D3 supplements
  • Phosphate binders
    • Sevelamer
    • Calcium carbonate and acetate
  • Cinacalcet

Renal replacement therapy

Decision is made at grade 4 CKD

  • Allogeneic kidney transplant
  • Hemodialysis: 4 hours per session, three times a week.
  • Peritoneal dialysis

questions.text: A 78-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department in a semi-conscious state with no available medical history. Physical examination revealed a foul-smelling, pungent breath, an arteriovenous (AV) fistula in the left arm, bilateral lower limb oedema, multiple bruises and abrasions on the body, and Kussmaul respirations. A bedside blood glucose measurement showed a level of 200 mg/dL. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Complications of Chronic Kidney Disease

Fluid and electrolytes

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Pitting oedema (Due to fluid and salt retention)
  • Uremic acidosis
    • It occurs due to the build-up of uremic toxins in the body due to reduced renal function.
    • Features: Uremic fetor, Kussmaul breathing, reduced cognitive ability, confusion/coma.

Cardiovascular system

  • Uremic pericarditis
  • Cardiac failure occurs due to salt and water retention, left ventricular hypertrophy, diastolic dysfunction, frank cardiomyopathy and myocardial ischemia.
  • Vascular calcifications occur due to hyperphosphatemia.

Haematological system

  • Abnormal hemostasis
    • Coagulopathies
    • Thromboembolism (in cases of hypoalbuminemia)
  • Anemia occurs due to reduced EPO secretion: Normocytic normochromic anemia

Skin changes

  • Nephrogenic fibrosing dermopathy (Progressive subcutaneous induration)
  • Calciphylaxis - build up of calcium in small arterioles of skin and fat tissue.
    • Painful livedo reticularis and subcutaneous nodules
    • Ischemic necrosis patches, especially over the legs, thighs, abdomen and breast
  • Pruritus and easy bruisability.
 

Calciphylaxis

 

Nephrogenic fibrosing dermopathy

 

 

Musculoskeletal
  • Osteitis fibrosa cystica (Due to secondary hyperparathyroidism)
  • Osteomalacia (Due to reduced levels of Vitamin D and low bone turnover)

Nervous system

  • Hyperuremic encephalopathy
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Restless leg syndrome

questions.text: A 38-year-old male with end-stage renal disease is being evaluated for kidney transplantation. Which of the following investigations is essential to perform on the recipient to list him for transplantation?

Which of the following statements are true regarding HLA matching for renal transplants? Only HLA - A and HLA - DR needs to be matched Life-long immunosuppressive therapy is essential post-transplant ⅚ HLA match required no induction therapy Tacrolimus and Basiliximab are used for induction therapy
Which type of graft rejection is resistant to therapy and, hence, is the leading cause of graft failure?
During a hemodialysis session, the dialysis nurse notices the patient experiencing hypotension. Which of the following strategies might be employed to help manage this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase the blood flow rate through the dialyser

options.label: B
options.text: Reduce the dialysate sodium concentration gradually

options.label: C
options.text: Reduce the concentration of potassium in the dialysate

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease the duration of the dialysis session

questions.correct_answer: B. Reduce the dialysate sodium concentration gradually

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is evaluated for hemodialysis. The patient presents with fluid overload, hyperkalemia, and significant lethargy. Which of the following is not an indication for initiating hemodialysis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Indication

Acute (AKI)

Chronic(CKD)

Fluid Overload
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Severe Hypertension
  • Edema resistant to diuretics

Hyperkalemia
  • >6.5 mmol/L with ECG changes (Broad QRS)
  • Potassium resistant to treatment

Uraemia
  • Pericarditis
  • Encephalopathy
  • Uremic syndrome (anorexia, nausea, lethargy, etc.), typically when eGFR < 10 mL/min/1.73 m²

Metabolic Acidosis
  • Severe acidosis

(H+ > 79 nmol/L; pH < 7.1)
  • Chronic acidosis resistant to bicarbonate therapy

Relative indications
  • Bleeding diathesis due to uremia-induced platelet dysfunction
  • Intractable anemia despite erythropoietin and iron supplementation
  • Hyperphosphatemia despite phosphate binders

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient undergoing hemodialysis suddenly develops symptoms of dizziness, significant leg cramps, and chest pain during the treatment session. Which of the following is the most common acute complication occurring in patients undergoing dialysis?
questions.explanation:
Intermittent Hemodialysis

Continuous Hemodialysis
  • Commonly used for acute kidney injury (AKI).
  • Blood is on one side of the dialysis machine, and dialysate is on the other side.
  • Transfer of substances occurs by diffusion and ultrafiltration.
  • Common complication: Hypotension.

 
  • Used in hemodynamically unstable patients.
  • Types:
    • Convective Clearance: Water and dissolved solutes pass through a semipermeable membrane; physiologic crystalloid solution is added to circulation.
    • Diffusive Clearance: Dialysis with a lower flow rate.
    • Hybrid Therapy: Combines both convective and diffusive clearance.

Complications associated with Hemodialysis

During treatment

Between treatment
  • Hypotension: The most common acute complication during hemodialysis, especially in patients with diabetes mellitus.
  • Muscle cramps.
  • Anaphylactoid reactions: These reactions, particularly to the dialyser, are most common during its first use and are often associated with bio incompatible cellulosic-containing membranes.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias: D/t potassium & acid-base shifts.
  • Hemorrhage: D/t anticoagulation & venous needle disconnection.
  • Air embolism: D/t faulty lines & equipment malfunction.
  • Pulmonary oedema (D/t fluid overload).
  • Systemic sepsis: Usually involves vascular access devices (catheter or fistula).
  • Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome typically occurs during or after a patient's first dialysis session. It presents with confusion, restlessness, headache, and muscle twitching. It is caused by a urea gradient between the CSF and blood that raises intracranial pressure.
  • Amyloidosis (D/t beta 2 microglobulin)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome (due to amyloid deposition in the flexor retinaculum).
  • Peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: Which is the most common opportunistic infection post kidney transplant and the time during which it occurs?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral candidiasis - within 1 month of transplantation

options.label: C
options.text: Listeria monocytogenes - within 1- 6 months of transplantation

options.label: D
options.text: BK virus - after 6 months of transplantation

questions.correct_answer: B. Cytomegalovirus - within 1- 6 months of transplantation
questions.explanation:
Complications following Renal transplant

Graft rejection

Hyperacute, acute and chronic

Opportunistic infections
  • < 1 Month: Wound infection, HSV, UTI, Oral candidiasis
  • 1-6 Months: CMV (most common), HBV, HCV, Pneumocystis carinii, Listeria
  • >6 Months: BK Virus, Aspergillus, Nocardia, HBV, HCV, HZV

Hypercalcemia

This may indicate failure of parathyroid gland regression post-transplant.

Anemia
  • Common post-transplant, often due to immunosuppressive medications.
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding can occur from steroid use.

Chronic hepatitis

Particularly from hepatitis B virus, which can progress over time.

Skin and lip cancers

Most common malignancy

The leading causes of death among kidney transplant recipients include:

  • Cardiovascular events (29%)
  • Infections (18%)
  • Malignancies (17%)

questions.text: What is the cause of hyperacute graft rejection?
questions.explanation:
Causes of graft rejection

Hyperacute rejection

(Option C)

Occurs due to the presence of preformed antibodies targeting antigens on graft endothelial cells - Type-2 Hypersensitivity reaction

It can occur immediately after graft implantation or during blood flow restoration of the graft

Acute Rejection

Occurs due to (Type-4 Hypersensitivity reaction)

Types

  • Cellular Rejection (Option A)
    • CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) directly destroy graft cells
    • CD4+ T cells induce inflammation that damages the graft.
  • Antibody-Mediated Rejection: Antibodies bind to vascular endothelium, activating the complement, leading to inflammation and graft failure.
 

It can occur within days to weeks of transplantation.

Chronic Rejection

Occurs due to T cells reacting against graft alloantigens, which secrete cytokines that stimulate fibroblast and vascular smooth muscle cell proliferation.
